The emergency response program is updated as needed to address changes to Westlake processes. The Management of Change process is used to trigger updates to the emergency response plan, including notification and training of personnel affected by the change. 

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Westlake implemented a project that significantly modifies the potential footprint of a methyl mercaptan release from the site.  Historically, the site purchased methyl mercaptan as a raw material.  Due to the toxic nature of methyl mercaptan, Westlake invested in facilities to import an alternate raw material that dissociates into methyl mercaptan and other components on an as needed basis.  This resulted in no on-site storage of methyl mercaptan.  The alternative release scenario represented in the current RMP is from the potential in process losses of the generated methyl mercaptan.

Diligent compliance with our RMP Prevention Program forms the framework on which we will continue to improve the level of safety at the facility. Some of the key components of the safety improvements we expect to achieve are as follows:

1.  The Management of Change provisions ensure that we consider the potential safety and health impacts of any change we make to process chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.

2.  The Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in our safety standards.  PHAs are revalidated at least every 5-years by a team of process operators and unit engineers.

3.  Following a maintenance turnaround or change implementation, Pre-Start-Up Safety Reviews are conducted to ensure that the process is safe to operate, procedures are in place and affected personnel are adequately trained to operate or maintain the process.

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM
The overall emergency response program for the Westlake facility is coordinated with the Shell Deer Park Chemical Plant and Pemex's Deer Park Refinery through a service agreement with Shell.  Westlake also works closely with the City of Deer Park's Department of Emergency Services and Harris County's Office of Homeland Security & Emergency Management (OHSEM).  

This coordination includes periodic meetings with or communications to local emergency response officials, local government officials, community members, and industry representatives. Shell, Pemex and Westlake maintain trained and fully equipped firefighting, HAZMAT, and medical/rescue teams capable of managing a broad range of emergency incidents. 

Westlake also maintains 24-hour communications capability with relevant public agencies, as well as area emergency response organizations (i.e. local fire department, local pollution control agencies, federal agencies, etc.).  Westlake Health, Safety and Environmental personnel are trained to make required notifications to the public agencies as well as to the public via the CAER phone line and emails to the Deer Park Community Advisory Council in the event of a release.

Westlake (through Shell and Pemex) maintains a written emergency response program designed to protect workers, public safety, and the environment. This program consists of policies and procedures for responding to releases, including actions to be taken in the event of a fire, explosion, or chemical release. These procedures address all aspects of emergency response, including first aid and medical treatment, evacuation, and personnel accountability plans. In addition, there are procedures that address maintenance, inspection, testing, and use of emergency response equipment. FACILITY DESCRIPTION AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES
The Westlake Deer Park facility has processes with regulated substances in sufficient quantities to be covered under the Risk Management Program (RMP) regulation. The facility is classified as Program Level 3 under the RMP regulation since the site is also required to comply with Occupational Safety and Health Administration's (OSHA) 1910.119 Process Safety Management regulations. The RMP regulated substances stored or processed at this facility include methyl mercaptan, epichlorohydrin and pentane.  

ACCIDENT PREVENTION PROGRAM
Westlake's committed and engaged leaders and associates strive to create a safe environment for ourselves and the communities.  Part of our program involves identifying and taking steps to avoid potential accidental chemical releases. This is accomplished through Process Hazard Analyses and periodic review of policies and procedures. Additionally, the site has various safety features to detect, contain and control, and mitigate the consequences of a release that include:

1. Release detection
   Process alarms
   Operator surveillance
   Portable hydrocarbon monitoring equipment 

2. Release containment and control
   Relief systems designed to prevent equipment over-pressurization (i.e. relief valves and flare)
   Dikes to contain liquid releases
   Automatic control valves to allow rapid isolation of the process

3. Release Mitigation
   Area firewater monitors
   Mobile emergency response equipment
   Trained emergency response personnel

Executive Summary
Westlake Epoxy Inc.  
Deer Park, Texas
(EPA ID: 1000 0017 5614)

Effective February 1, 2022, as part of Westlake Chemical Corporation's (Westlake) announced acquisition of Hexion Inc.'s global epoxy business, Hexion Inc.'s operations at 5900 Highway 225, Gate 7B, Deer Park, TX  77536 were transferred to Westlake's subsidiary, Hexion Coatings and Composites (US) Inc.  Effective April 15, 2022, the name has changed to Westlake Epoxy Inc.

The Westlake Epoxy Inc. facility in Deer Park, TX, referred to as Westlake, is a manufacturing facility owned by Westlake Epoxy Inc. The facility is located on Highway 225 in Deer Park, Texas. Westlake sells resins & its precursors to other chemical companies that transform them into thousands of consumer products ranging from plastics and coatings to electronics and wind energy. About 150 full-time employees work at the site.

INTRODUCTION AND POLICIES
Westlake is committed to the continuous improvement of chemical safety management. Westlake maintains Health, Safety and Environmental (HSE) management systems to ensure the safe operation of its facilities is safe for our workers, the public, and environment. As part of this commitment, Westlake invests resources in various areas of accident prevention, such as:

* Safety in process design;
* Safe operating policies and procedures;
* A comprehensive mechanical integrity program;
* Management of process changes;
* Training;
* Incident investigation and auditing; and
* Emergency response participation.

Westlake works closely with our Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and Community Advisory Council (CAC).
